titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Cary Reich papers FA1275

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-09-02 09:16:17 -0400.

physdesc.extent: 10 standard record storage boxes, 10 document boxes containing 565 audio cassettes, and 2 record storage boxes containing special formats.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection primarily contains transcripts, audiotapes, and notes of interviews conducted by author Cary Reich during research for the first volume, and anticipated second volume, of "The Life of Nelson A. Rockefeller." Additionally, it contains partial audiotaped interviews for Reich's New York Times expose "The Creative Mind: The Innovator," which appeared on April 21, 1985, as well as for other financial articles.

In addition, there are audio interviews conducted by Patricia Linden for a "Town and Country" magazine article ("The Rockefellers' Monumental Legacy," September 1982) describing the Rockefeller legacy in New York, as well as for her own unrealized, unauthorized biography of Nelson Rockefeller.

Lastly, the collection has subject files primarily consisting of research materials and news clippings pertaining to a variety of significant events in Nelson Rockfeller's professional life, including but not limited to the 1964 U.S. presidential campaign, the International Basic Economy Corporation (IBEC), his tenure as Governor of New York, and the U.S. vice presidency.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Papers were transferred to RAC in 2012 by the estate of Cary Reich.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Cary Reich Papers were donated to Rockefeller Archive Center in 2012. The Cary Reich estate retains copyright and all associated intellectual property rights.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Transcripts of dozens of interviews conducted by Cary Reich, the audio of which are in Series 2. Additionally, there are some of Reich's reference files compiled during the course of his research for the biography, comprised of mostly clippings and copies of articles or transcripts from other sources.

scopecontent.p: A lawyer who served as a personal advisor to Nelson Rockefeller. Under Governor Rockefeller, Ruebhausen served in a number of capacities, including as chair of the Special Task Force on Protection from Radioactive Fallout, as Special Adviser on Atomic Energy, and as chair of a panel on insurance holding companies. He also served as one of Governor Rockefeller's executors.

scopecontent.p: Dr. Wharton's long association with Nelson Rockefeller began with the American International Association for Economic and Social Development (AIA) in 1948. He served as associate and then as director of operations for the American Development Council from 1958 to 1964. He was a member of Nelson Rockefeller's presidential mission to Latin America in 1969 on behalf of Richard Nixon. In October 1969, Wharton was elected president of Michigan State University, becoming the first African-American president of a major U.S. university. In 1978, he became chancellor of the State University of New York (SUNY) system. In 1982, Wharton was named chair of the Rockefeller Foundation.

scopecontent.p: Executive director of the New York State Republican Committee from 1959 to 1965, followed by two years serving as Appointments Officer. Then Governor Nelson Rockefeller appointed Scelsi to the New York State Civil Service Commission.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Curator at the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA) and a consultant and curator for numerous art projects for the Rockefeller family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cousin of Mary (Tod) Rockefeller and a curator (1934-1946) and director (1938-1946) at the Brooklyn Museum. Under his leadership, the Brooklyn Museum produced numerous exhibitions and programs on Latin America, with extensive collaboration with Nelson Rockefeller and the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, under whose auspices the museum produced and circulated traveling exhibitions. Roberts was also involved in the founding of the New York State Council on the Arts in 1960 and 1961.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lawyer and financial adviser to the Rockefeller family and manager of Room 5600.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Republican New York state senator and then a member of the U.S. House of Representatives.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Democratic member of the New York State Assembly from 1969 to 1974. During his first year in office, he successfully sued Governor Nelson Rockefeller regarding the budgetary process.

scopecontent.p: Deputy controller of the State of New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.p: Chancellor of the State University of New York (SUNY) system.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Wife of Erastus Corning, who was the mayor of Albany.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These folders contain copies of transcripts of interviews conducted by Cary Reich or others with former IBEC staff members. Nelson Rockefeller created IBEC in 1947 to promote "basic economies" in developing countries and thus encourage others in those countries to establish competitive businesses. Rockefeller served as president of IBEC until 1958, when he resigned to assume his duties as Governor of New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Saratoga, NY, socialite known for her excellent race horses.

scopecontent.p: Photocopies and transcripts of articles or oral histories related to Happy Rockefeller, who married Nelson Rockefeller in 1963.

scopecontent.p: Copies of article, chapters, and press releases related to the office of the Vice President of the United States and Nelson Rockefeller's nomination by Gerald Ford to fill the position after Ford became President in August 1974.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of audiotaped interviews conducted by author Cary Reich for the first volume, and anticipated second volume, of "The Life of Nelson A. Rockefeller." Additionally, there are partial audiotaped interviews for Reich's "New York Times" expose "The Creative Mind: The Innovator," from April 21, 1985, as well as for other financial articles by Reich.

Lastly, the series contains audio interviews conducted by Patricia Linden for a "Town and Country" magazine article ("Rockefellers' Monumental Legacy," September 1982) that highlights the Rockefeller legacy in New York. She was also working on her own unrealized, unauthorized biography of Nelson Rockefeller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Abramovitz was an architect and business partner of Wallace Harrison. Interview with Abramovitz ends at 93 minutes, 52 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with two unidentified individuals until tape ends at 233 minutes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Abrams worked on Nelson Rockefeller's campaigns for the Republican presidential nomination in 1964 and 1968.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Adams was White House Chief of Staff during President Dwight D. Eisenhower's administration. He had previously served as Governor of New Hampshire. Adams interview ends at 242 minutes, 39 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Marylou Whitney until end.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Albright was an aide to Nelson Rockefeller, 1967-1975. During Rockefeller's governorship, Albright held various positions, including deputy secretary, executive secretary, and appointments officer. He was also state banking superintendent, 1972-1974. He then served has Rockefeller's special counsel when Rockefeller was Vice President.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Albright was an aide to Nelson Rockefeller, 1967-1975. During Rockefeller's governorship, Albright held various positions, including deputy secretary, executive secretary, and appointments officer. He was also state banking superintendent, 1972-1974. He then served has Rockefeller's special counsel when Rockefeller was Vice President.

scopecontent.p: Interview. Aldrich was a cousin of Nelson Rockefeller who served as special assistant on race relations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Aldrich was a cousin of Nelson Rockefeller; IBEC associate and later board member; advance team for 1969 Presidnetial Mission to Latin America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Aldrich was a Cousin of Nelson Rockefeller; IBEC associate and later board member; advance team for 1969 Presidnetial Mission to Latin America. Aldrich interview ends at 57 minutes, 30 seconds. Tape then contains partial interviews with two unidentified individuals until end.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Aldrich was a cousin of Governor Nelson Rockefeller's who served as special assistant on race relations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Andre was a New York State Republican committee chair and then Clinton County Republican chair. He previously was a state trooper and worked security at the State House in Albany. Andre interview ends at 86 minutes, 26 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Paul Volker until end. Volcker was an economist for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York (1952-1957) and then at Chase Manhattan Bank (1957-1962). He was later Chair of the U.S. Federal Reserve from 1979 to 1987.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Armao was a labor relations aide. Armao interview ends at 71 minutes, 14 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Dan Mahoney until end. Mahoney helped found the New York Conservative Party in 1962.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Arndt was an IBEC aide. No aduio for the first 30 minutes, 17 seconds.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Aurelio was a journalist and campaign manager for New York City Mayor John Lindsay in 1969. Aurelio interview ends at 143 minutes, 36 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with unidentified Beth Moore until end. Moore was chairman of the board of the State University of New York and friend of Nelson Rockefeller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Bagley was a World War II war correspondent in Brazil who became director of public relations for AIA and IBEC under Nelson Rockefeller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Barclay was a New York State senator.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Interview ends at 30 minutes, 15 seconds. Remainder of tape is blank.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Berger was executive director of the Scott Commission, 1972-1973, and a consultant to the Rockefeller Commission on Critical Choices for Americans, 1973-1974. He was also executive director of the New York Emergency Control Board for the City of New York. Berger interview ends at 47 minutes. Tape then contains interivew with Arthur Richardson until end. Richardson was a campaign aide to Nelson Rockefeller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Berger was executive director of the Scott Commission, 1972-1973, and a consultant to the Rockefeller Commission on Critical Choices for Americans, 1973-1974. He was also executive director of the New York Emergency Control Board for the City of New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Bigel was a labor union consultant and negotiator.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Bixby was chairman of the New York State Thruway Authority, 1960-1970, and managed Governor Nelson Rockefeller's re-election campaign in 1970. Bixby interview ends at 31 minutes, 20 seconds. Tape continues with interview with Dorothy Miller. Miller was a curator at the Museum of Modern Art and a consulatant and curator for numerous art projects for the Rockefeller family. Miller interview ends at 63 minutes. Tape continues with interview with Bixby. Bixby interview ends at 105 minutes, 20 seconds. Tape continues with interview with William Alton. Alton was a friend and IBEC aide. Alton interview ends at 107 minutes, 37 seconds. Tape continues with interviews with multiple unidentified individuals until 157 minutes, 17 seconds. Tape continues with interview with Bixby until end.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview with art photographer Lee Bolton. Collaborated with Nelson Rockefeller in the 1970s on art book projects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Bowker was chancellor of the City University of New York and then the University of California, Berkeley. Bowker interview ends at 65 minutes, 52 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Charles Webb until end. Webb was counsel to New York State Assemblyman Perry Duryea and worked on the reapportionment of legislature districts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview with Joseph Boyd, Governor Nelson Rockefeller's Congressional liaison officer in Washington, DC. Boyd also served as the Governor's liaison to the New York State legislature.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Boyer was chancellor of the State University of New York system.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Braden was a friend of Nelson Rockefeller and a Rockefeller family aide. Braden interview ends at 132 minutes, 54 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with George Shapiro until end. Shapiro was counsel to New York Governor Thomas Dewey.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Braden was a friend and family aide. Braden interview ends at 118 minutes, 44 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Rodman Rockefeller until end. Rodman Rockefeller was the son of Nelson Rockefeller. He was vice president of the International Basic Economy Corporation, 1968 to 1972, and its chief executive, 1972 to 1980.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Brinton was national chair for the Draft Rockefeller movement in 1960. Tape begins with partial interview with Josh Friedman. Friedman was a reporter for the New York Post. Brinton interview begins at 5 minutes, 18 seconds and ends at 27 minutes, 48 seconds. Tape continues with interview with Friedman until end.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Bronston served several terms as a Democrat from New York City in the State Senate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Richard A. Brown was the legislative representative for New York City, 1970-1973. Brown interview ends at 87 minutes, 22 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with William Golub until end. Golub was an attorney who was special assistant to Governor Nelson Rockefeller for rail and commuter problems. He was also special consultant to the Moreland Act Commission to draft legislation that created sweeping changes in New York State's liquor laws.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Tape then contains partial interview with Evelyn Cunningham until end. Cunningham was a reporter for the Pittsburgh Courier in its Harlem office and then special assistant to Governor Nelson Rockefeller. She was appointed director of the Women's Unit within the Governor's Office.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Burbank was a campaign and family aide.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Tape then contains partial interview with Warren Weaver until end. Weaver covered Nelson Rockefeller's early political campagins for the New York Times.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Pitch is too high, speed is too fast, and audio crackles for first 22 minutes, 29 seconds, making the interview unintelligible in parts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Carey was a Democratic Governor of New York who beat Republican Malcolm Wilson (who served out Nelson Rockefeller's fourth term). Previously had served several terms in the U.S. House of Representatives.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Compilation: Barber Conable, John Sears, Oscar Lanford, John Egan, Charles Lanigan, Lois Wilson

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Conable was a New York state senator and then a member of the U.S. House of Representatives. Conable interview ends at 47 minutes, 10 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Sears until 72 minutes, 43 seconds. Sears was Ronald Reagan's campaign manager during the 1976 Republican presidential primaries. Tape then contains partial interview with Lanford until 94 minutes, 24 seconds. Lanford was the president of SUNY Fredonia. Tape then contains partial interview with Egan until 150 minutes, 14 seconds. Egan was commissioner of the New York Office of General Services. Tape then contains partial interview with Lanigan until 188 minutes, 30 seconds. Lanigan was mayor of Rome, New York, 1959-1962, and later was on Governor Nelson Rockefeller's staff for six years in various capacities. Tape then contains partial interview with Wilson until 233 minutes, 32 seconds. Wilson was a gubernatorial aide to Governor Nelson Rockefeller. Tape then contains partial interview with unidentified individual until end.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Conable was a Republican New York State senator and then a member of the U.S. House of Representatives. Conable interview ends at 51 minutes, 40 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Oscar Ruebhausen until end. Ruebhausen was a friend and advisor to Nelson Rockefeller. Under Governor Rockefeller, Ruebhausen served in a number of capacities, including as chairman of the Special Task Force on Protection from Radioactive Fallout, as Special Adviser on Atomic Energy, and as chairman of a panel on insurance holding companies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Coral was chair of Independents for Rockefeller in his early campaigns. Was involved with the League of Women Voters. Conducted by phone.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Chair of New York County Democratic Committee in 1960s; appointed by Governor Nelson Rockefeller to the commission that investigated New York City government in the 1970s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Crangle was Erie County (NY) Democratic chair and then New York State Democratic chair. Crangle interview ends at 93 minutes, 24 seconds. Tape then contains interview with Charles Rangel until end. Rangel was a Democratic New York State Assembly member from 1967 to 1970 and a member of the U.S. House of Representatives for district including Harlem from 1971 to 2017. Governor Nelson Rockefeller endorsed Rangel for his 1968 reelection to the New York State Assembly.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Crown was a film producer who worked in the motion picture divison of the State Department in Latin America during World War 2 showing United States propaganda films to local heads of companies. Outside of that, Crown was president of Moulin Productions and later vice president of international sales for Samuel Goldwyn Productions and R.K.O. Pictures, and he worked for Allied Artists and Aladan Productions. At the time of his death, he was senior vice president in charge of Penthouse Films International Ltd.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Cunningham was a reporter for the Pittsburgh Courier in its Harlem office and special assistant to Governor Nelson Rockefeller. She was appointed director of the Women's Unit within the Governor's Office.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Cuomo was Secretary of State of New York, 1975-1978, Lieutenant Governor of New York, 1979-1982, and then Governor of New York, 1983-1994. Cuomo interview ends at 68 minutes, 35 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with unidentified individual until end.

Diamond interivew ends at 55 minutes, 23 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Gillies. Gillies was an IBEC aide. Gillies interview ends at 91 minutes, 23 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with unidentified individal until 94 minutes. Tape then continues with interview with Diamond until end.

scopecontent.p: Interview. Richardson was a lawyer and financial adviser to the Rockefeller family and manager of Room 5600.

scopecontent.p: Interview. Dominick was a member of the New York State Assembly and then a New York State senator from Newburgh.

He also served with Rockefeller at various times in the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs; International Basic Economy Corporation; New York State Office of Regional Development; and the Pure Water Authority.

did.unittitle: Ford: Panel IIA: The Rockefeller Vice Presidency

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Panelists include Richard Rosenbaum, Joseph Persico, Peter Wallison, Richard Dunham, and James Cannon. Rosenbaum was appointed by Governor Nelson Rockefeller to the New York State Supreme Court. Persico was chief speech writer for Rockefeller when he was governor and vice president. Wallison was special assistant to Governor Rockefeller and Counsel to the Vice President. Dunham was deputy director and then director of the budget for New York. Cannon was associate to Governor Rockefeller and then to the Vice President.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Lovelock was a detective lieutenant for the NYPD and a bodyguard for Governor Nelson Rockefeller.

Eisenhower, and he was a consultant to Rockefeller when Rockefeller served as President Eisenhower's special assistant for Foreign Affairs. Haskell interview ends at 136 minutes, 10 seconds. scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Hiss was involved in the establishment of the United Nations both as a U.S. State Department official and as a United Nations official. At the United Nations Conference on International Organization (the convention that created the U.N. charter), Hiss and Nelson Rockefeller were members of the United States delegation, with Hiss also serving as secretary general of the conference. Hiss and some other members of the U.S. delegation opposed the admission of Argentina while Rockefeller supported the country's admission.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Hiss was the brother of Alger Hiss and worked in the State Department during World War II. His work focused on limiting German economic interests in Latin America.

Among other things, he designed the Rockefeller Guest House for the family. Johnson interview ends at 31 minutes, 14 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with John Debbink until end. scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Lindsay served in the U.S. House of Representatives, 1959-1965, and was mayor of New York, 1966 to 1973, during much of Nelson Rockefeller's tenure as Governor of New York. scopecontent.p: Interview. McWhorter was a lawyer and aide to Richard Nixon.

Miller interview ends at 198 minutes, 3 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with investment banker Michel David-Weil until 208 minutes. Tape then contains no content until interview with Miller and an unidentified woman begins at 217 minutes, 28 seconds and lasts until the end of the tape.

Gwirtzman was an advisor and speech writer for John, Bobby, and Edward Kennedy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Mitchell was a long-time associate of Nelson Rockefeller, beginning with his service in the Eisenhower administration on the committee to reorganize the federal government (PACGO/SCOGO) and then the newly created Department of Health, Education, and Welfare. Mitchell interview ends at 118 minutes, 48 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Edward Kresky until end. Kresky was a gubernatorial aide to Nelson Rockefeller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Mitrovich was press secretary for U.S. Senator Charles Goodell, who was apppointed by Governor Nelson Rockefeller to fill the seat after Senator Robert F. Kennedy's assassination in 1968. Interview was conducted by phone rather than in person. Mitrovich interview ends at 82 minutes, 7 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Edward Cain until end. Cain was chair of the Genesee County Republican Committee.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Moore was chairman of the board of the State University of New York and friend of Nelson Rockefeller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. During the 1968 Republican presidential primaries, Moore was foreign policy advisor to Michigan Governor George Romney and then foreign policy advisor to Governor Nelson Rockefeller after Romney dropped out of the campaign.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Moreira Salles was a Brazilian banker and philanthropist who was an investor in Nelson Rockefeller's International Basic Economy Corporation (IBEC). He was also a friend of David Rockefeller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Morgenthau was the 1962 Democratic nominee for Governor of New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Morhouse was the son of L. Judson Morhouse, who was Republican state chairman of New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Morrison was Liberal Party of New York leader.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Mottahedeh co-founded a well-regarded company that produced porcelain reproductions for museums and historical sites. Her company produced several of the porcelain items sold by the Nelson Rockefeller Collection Inc. (NRC Inc.), established after Vice President Rockefeller left office. Mottahedeh interview ends at 30 minutes, 42 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Robert Stone until end. Stone served as Executive Deputy Secretary of State and then Deputy Commissioner of General Services under Governor Nelson Rockefeller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Moylan was New York State Commerce Commissioner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Moynihan was a Democratic U.S. Senator from New York from 1977 to 2001; previously, he was a member of Governor Averell Harriman's staff and a member of the Presidential administrations of John F. Kennedy, Lyndon Johnson, Richard Nixon, and Gerald Ford. Moynihan interview ends at 57 minutes, 11 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Daniel Button until 104 minutes, 18 seconds. Button was assistant to the president of the State University of New York (SUNY), 1952-1958; executive editor of the Albany Times Union newspaper, 1960-1966; and a Republican member of the U.S. House of Representatives, 1967-1971. Tape then contintues with interview with Moynihan until 114 minutes, 6 seconds. Tape then contains two separate partial interviews with unidentified individuals until end.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Murray worked for New York politician Frank Moore in various capacities during the 1950s and 1960s and served as acting chief administrative officer of the State University of New York, 1963-1964. Murray interview ends at 150 minutes, 49 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with George Gilder until end. Gilder was a speechwriter for Nelson Rockefeller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Musicus served Governor Nelson Rockefeller as Assistant Secretary for Administration; later served on staff of Mayor John Lindsay. Musicus interview ends at 74 minutes, 20 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Alexander Lankler until end. Lankler was a campaign aide to Governor Rockefeller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Nathan was an ddvisor to Governor Nelson Rockefeller and, later, director of the Rockefeller Institute of Government.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Neuberger was a financier, philanthropist, and art collector who knew Governor Nelson Rockefeller throught their mutual love of modern art. Neuberger interview ends at 76 minutes, 4 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Peter Cohen. Cohen was CEO of Shearson Lehman Brothers. The Cohen interview is not connected to Reich's Rockefeller book.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Newman was a Republican leader who was appointed to the New York State Supreme Court by Governor Nelson Rockefeller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Nitze was the financial division director when Nelson Rockefeller was Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs for the Roosevelt administration during World War II. Nitze interview ends at 53 minutes, 1 second. Tape then contains partial interview with Herbert Brownell until end. Brownell was the U.S. Attorney General during the first Eisenhower administration.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. O'Brien was the Rockefeller family's lawyer for five decades.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. O'Connor was district attorney of Queens, 1955-1965, and the Democratic nominee for governor of New York in 1966. He was president of the New York City Council, 1966-1968, and a Justice of the New York State Supreme Court, 1969-1979. O'Donnell was an aide to O'Connor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. O'Neill was Nelson Rockefelelr's niece.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. O'Shaughnessy was a broadcaster and writer. He was general manager of radio station WVOX in 1965 and bought the station three years later along with WTRN.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Ogden was an architect who worked on many Rockefeller projects as well as IBEC housing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Oldenburg was director of the Museum of Modern Art, 1972-1995.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Ortiz was an American International Association for Economic and Social Development (AIA) aide.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Ottinger was a Democrat who served as U.S. Representative for the 24th and later 25th districts of New York from the 1960s to 1980s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. General Parker (U.S. Army) first served on the staff of Nelson Rockfeller during his tenure in the Eisenhower Administation as Special Assistant to the President for Foreign Affairs. Parker later served as New York State Commissioner of Transporation. Parker interview ends at 134 minutes, 50 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Richard Dunham until end. Dunham was deputy budget director and then director of the budget for Governor Nelson Rockefeller. Dunham was also deputy director of the White House Domestic Council when Rockefeller was Vice President.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

She subsequently helpd found the museum's International Council on which she served as president from 1957 to 1966. Parkinson interview ends at 35 minutes, 20 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with an unidentified individual regarding investment banking that is unrelated to Reich's Nelson Rockefeller biography.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Parkinson was chairman of the Junior Advisory Committee at the Musuem of Modern Art at the invitation of Nelson Rockefeller. She subsequently helpd found the museum's International Council on which she served as president from 1957 to 1966.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Perkins served on the staff of Nelson Rockefeller while he was President Eisenhower's Assistant Secretary for the U.S. Health, Education, and Welfare Department; First Counsel to the Governor for Nelson Rockefeller; Platform planning for 1960 and 1964 Presidential campaigns.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Perkins Served on the staff of Nelson Rockefeller while he was President Eisenhower's Assistant Secretary for the U.S. Health, Education, and Welfare Department; First Counsel to the Governor for Nelson Rockefeller; Platform planning for 1960 and 1964 Presidential campaigns. Perkins interview ends at 312 minutes, 30 seconds. Tape then contains partial interivew with Sheldon Stark until end. Stark was a classmate of Nelson Rockefeller at the Lincoln School and Dartmouth College.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Perrotta was assistant counsel to the Governor for Nelson Rockefeller; then New York City coordinator of Rockefeller's 1970 gubernatorial campaign. Perrotta interview ends at 127 minutes, 57 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Nelson Rockefeller's brother Laurance Rockefeller until 187 minutes, 16 seconds. Tapen then contains partial interview with Paul Nitze until 237 minutes, 12 seconds. Nitze was director of the financial division of the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs under Nelson Rockefeller. Tape then repeats part of Perrotta interview until 267 minutes, 37 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with unidentified individual regarding investment banking until end. This interview is not connected to Reich's Nelson Rockefeller biography.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Percy was a Republican from Illinois who served in the U.S. Senate from the 1960s to the 1980s. His daughter Sharon married Nelson Rockefeller's nephew Jay (John D. IV).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Phelan, from Buffalo, was Counsel to New York State Senate Majority Leader Earl Brydges. Phelan interview ends at 145 minutes, 12 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Alton Marshall until end. Marshall was Secretary to the Governor for Nelson Rockefeller, 1965-1971, and later became president of Rockefeller Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Plaza was Ecuador's Ambassador to the United States, 1944-1946, President of Ecuador, 1948-1952, and Secretary General of the Organization of American States, 1968-1975.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Plumadore was a New York Republican who served as Harrietstown Town Attorney and Supervisor; later was in the State Assembly representing Franklin County, and was county chair for the Republican party.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Price was a campaign aide for Governor Nelson Rockefeller's 1968 presidential campaign. John Price interview ends at 94 minutes, 1 second. Tape then contains partial interview with Robert Price until end. Price managed Nelson Rockefeller's 1964 Republican presidential primary campaign for Oregon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Price was a laywer who worked on the Adirondack State Park proposal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Robert Price managed Nelson Rockefeller's 1964 Republican presidential primary campaign for Oregon. Price interview ends at 79 minutes, 13 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with unidentified individual regarding investment banking. This interview is not connected to Reich's biography on Nelson Rockfeller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Prideaux was a classmate of Nelson Rockefeller from the Lincoln School in Manhattan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Purcell was president of the International Basic Economy Corporation (IBEC). Purcell interview ends at 71 minutes, 58 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Alton Marshall until end. Marshall was Secretary to Governor Nelson Rockefeller and later became president of Rockefeller Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Reid worked in the speakers bureau during Governor Nelson Rockefeller's 1962 gubernatorial campaign. Reid also worked on securing delegates for Rockefeller during the 1968 Republican presidential primaries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Reid was appointed to the New York State Commission on Discrimination in 1961 by Governor Nelson Rockefeller. Also served six terms in the U.S. House of Representatives from 1963 to 1975. He switched parties from Republican to Democrat in 1972.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Robb was Chair of New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct and wife of newspaper publisher Gene Robb.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Roberts was staff director of the New York State Assembly Ways and Means Committee and member of the Albany Arts Council.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Roberts was a cousin of Mary (Tod) Rockefeller and a curator (1934-1946) and director (1938-1946) at the Brooklyn Museum. Under his leadership, the Brooklyn Museum produced numerous exhibitions and programs on Latin America, with extensive collaboration with Nelson Rockefeller and the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, under whose auspices the museum produced and circulated traveling exhibitions. Roberts was also involved in the founding of the New York State Council on the Arts in 1960 and 1961. Roberts interview ends at 30 minutes, 18 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with George Dudley until end. Dudley was an architect and gubernatorial aide to Nelson Rockefeller. Dudley worked alongside Wallace Harrison in designing and building the United Nations, Rockefeller Center, Lincoln Center, and the Empire State Plaza in Albany.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. David Rockefeller was Nelson Rockefeller's brother. Rockefeller interview ends at 184 minutes. Tape then contains partial interview with George Dudley until 220 minutes, 58 seconds. Dudley was an architect and gubernatorial aide to Nelson Rockefeller. Dudley worked alongside Wallace Harrison in designing and building the United Nations, Rockefeller Center, Lincoln Center, and the Empire State Plaza in Albany. Tape then continues with David Rockefeller interview until end.

did.unittitle: Nelson Rockefeller on the Phil Donahue Show; AND Adirondack Park Bill Signing Ceremony

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tape begins with audio from Nelson Rockefeller's appearance on the Phil Donahue Show (Show number 11187): interview topics are mostly art, his new art book publishing project, his new art reproduction business (Nelson Rockefeller Collection Inc.), and politics. Audio until 47 minutes, 16 seconds. Tape then contains audio from the Adirondack Park Bill Signing Ceremony on May 22, 1973, until 67 minutes. Tape is blank for the final six minutes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Nelson Rockefeller, Jr. is the son of Nelson Rockefeller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Rodman Rockefeller was the son of Nelson Rockefeller. He was vice president of the International Basic Economy Corporation, 1968 to 1972, and its chief executive, 1972 to 1980. Rockefeller interivew ends at 25 minutes, 42 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Alton Marshall until 47 minutes. Marshall was Governor Nelson Rockefeller's chief aide, 1965-1971, and later became president of Rockefeller Center. Tape then continues with Rodman Rockefeller interview until 278 minutes, 19 seconds. Tape then contains another partial interview with Marshall until end.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.p: Interview. Rogalin was vice chair of the New York State Republican Committee and president of its Women's Federation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. The governor of Michigan in the 1960s, Romney ran unsuccessfully for the Republican presidential nomination in 1968. He later served as U.S. Secretary of Housing and Urban Development in the Nixon administration.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Ronan was a long-time aide and advisor to Nelson Rockefeller and a senior advisor to the Rockefeller family. He designed and served as the first chairman of the New York City Metropolitan Transportation Authority, 1968-1974. He then served as chairman of the Port Authority of New Yokr and New Jersey, 1974-1977.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Rosenbaum was Monroe County (NY) Republican chair, 1968 to 1970; New York State Supreme Court justice, 1970 to 1972; and New York Republican State Committee chair from 1973 to 1977.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Rosenberg was a friend and public relations advisor to Nelson Rockefeller. She served in President Franklin Delano Roosevelt's administration and advocated for Rockefeller to Roosevelt, leading to his appointment as Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Rosenberger was Anna Rosenberg's son. Rosenbeg interivew ends at 54 minutes, 20 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with John Byron until end. Byron was director of construction of the South Mall for the State Office of General Services, an agency Governor Nelson Rockefeller created to oversee the project.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Tape contains two separate interviews with individuals about investment banking and are not connected to Reich's Nelson Rockefeller biography.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Ruebhausen was a lawyer who served as a personal advisor to Nelson Rockefeller. Under Governor Rockefeller, Ruebhausen served in a number of capacities, including as chair of the Special Task Force on Protection from Radioactive Fallout, as Special Adviser on Atomic Energy, and as chair of a panel on insurance holding companies. He also served as one of Governor Rockefeller's executors.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Ruggieri was chair of the New York City Democratic Party in the early 1970s. Also served as a lawyer representing the legislative and executive branches of New York State and New York City.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Rumsfeld was White House Chief of Staff and later Secretary of Defense during President Gerald Ford's administration. Rumsfeld interview ends at 77 minutes, 39 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with J. Lawrence Murray until end. Murray worked for New York politician Frank Moore in various capacities during the 1950s and 1960s and served as acting chief administrative officer of the State University of New York, 1963-1964.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Rumsfeld was White House Chief of Staff and later Secretary of Defense during President Gerald Ford's administration.

scopecontent.p: Interview. Rusher was publisher of National Review magazine who helped found the Conservative Party of New York in 1961 and the American Conservative Union in 1964. He worked on Senator Barry Goldwater's successful 1964 campaign for the Republican presidential nomination.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Interview. Rusher was publisher of National Review magazine who helped found the Conservative Party of New York in 1961 and the American Conservative Union in 1964. He worked on Senator Barry Goldwater's successful 1964 campaign for the Republican presidential nomination.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Ryan was Member of the New York State Assembly from the Capitol area in the 1960s through 1980s. He was known for opposing the creation of the Adirondack Park Agency by the state legislature.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Scelsi was executive director of the New York State Republican Committee from 1959 to 1965, followed by two years serving as Appointments Officer. Then Governor Nelson Rockefeller appointed Scelsi to the New York State Civil Service Commission. Scelsi interview ends at 148 minutes, 2 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with unidentified individual until end.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Schuler was instrumental in establishing the New York Department of Transportation and was appointed transportation commissioner in 1972 by Governor Nelson Rockefeller. Schuler was also the founder of The Business Council, New York's largest lobbying organization.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Schuler was instrumental in establishing the New York Department of Transportation and was appointed transportation commissioner in 1972 by Governor Nelson Rockefeller. Schuler was also the founder of The Business Council, New York's largest lobbying organization.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Schwenk was Republican Party chair of Suffolk County, New York, from 1967 to 1977.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Scribner was a Dartmouth classmate of Nelson Rockefeller. He served in the administration of President Dwight D. Eisenhower as UnderSecretary of the Treasury, and he later served as general counsel to the Republican National Committee. Scribner interivew ends at 70 minutes, 5 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with General Theodore Parker until end. Parker was a general in the United States Army and served on Nelson Rockefeller's staff when Rockefeller was Special Assistant to the President for Psychological Warfare. Parker also served as New York State Commissioner of Transportation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Sears was a Republican political strategist who served as advisor to Richard Nixon during the 1968 presidential campaign. He then was Deputy Counsel to President Nixon, 1969 to 1970, and managed Ronald Reagan's 1976 presidential campaign.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Seidman was executive director of Presdient Gerald Ford's Economic Policy Board and served as the president's assistant for economic affairs until 1977. Seidman interview ends at 46 minutes, 51 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Alan Miller until end. Miller was New York State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene, 1966-1975.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Shafer was Governor of Pennsylvania, 1967-1971, and gave the nominating speech for Governor Nelson Rockefeller at the 1968 Republican National Convention.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Shapiro was counsel to New York Governor Thomas Dewey.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Sharkey was chief of revenue estimating for the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance prior to Nelson Rockefeller's administration. He then worked on Governor Rockefeller's staff starting in 1959, where he focused on tax and budgeting projects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Sharkey was chief of revenue estimating for the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance. He moved on to work in the governor's office in 1959 where he worked on various tax and budgeting projects under Governor Nelson Rockefeller. Sharkey interview ends at 155 minutes, 4 seconds. Tape then contains a partial phone call with an unidentified individual until 159 minutes, 30 second. Tape then contains partial interview with Tanya Melich unitl end. Melich was an aide to Governor Nelson Rockefeller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Shaw was public relations director at the Museum of Modern Art.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Slater was an executive assistant to Governor Nelson Rockefeller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Slote was press secretary to Governor Nelson Rockefeller, 1966-1968. Slote interview ends at 32 minutes, 51 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with F. Clifton White until 47 minutes, 1 second. White was a political consultant and campaign manager for Republican Party and New York Conservative Party candidates. He was also a leader of the Draft Goldwater Committee, 1961-1964. Tapen then continues with Slote interview until end.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Spad was New York State Appointments Officer; State Chair of Young Republicans.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Spencer was a political aide for Nelson Rockefeller during the 1964 Republican presidential primaries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. St. Thomas was Republican party chair of Saratoga County, New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. St. Thomas was Republican party chair of Saratoga County, New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Stafford was a New York State senator from 1966 to 2002, for the district that includes a significant portion of Adirondack State Park. He was instrumental in bringing the internatioanl winter Olympics to Lake Placid in 1980.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Stark was a classmate of Nelson Rockefeller at the Lincoln School in Manhattan and Dartmouth College.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. As delegate at the conference that established the United Nations in 1945, Stassen was one of eight Americans who signed the UN Charter. (Nelson Rockefeller attended as well). Stassen then served in the adminstration of President Dwight D. Eisenhower for 5 years and unsuccessfully sought the Republican nomination for President 9 times between 1948 and 1988.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Steingut was a Democratic member of the New York state Assembly who served as Speaker of the Assembly in the 1970s. Previously, he was Brooklyn Democratic party chair.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Stephenson was British Prime Minister William Churchill's secret intelligence ambassdor to President Franklin D. Roosevelt. At the direction of Churchill, Stephenson established and ran the British Security Coordination, which was a covert organization operated out of Rockefeller Center with a purpose of investigating enemy activities, preventing sabotage against British interests in the Americas, and mobilizing pro-British opinion in the Americas. Stephenson supplied Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs Nelson Rockefeller with information on Nazi commercial activities in Latin America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. During Governor Nelson Rockefeller's second administration, Stewart was assistant counsel and then First Assistant Counsel to the Governor, and then served as New York State Insurance Commissioner during his third administration.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Stone served as Executive Deputy Secretary of State and then Deputy Commissioner of General Services under Governor Nelson Rockefeller. Stone interview ends at 86 minutes, 40 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Mike Scelsi until end. Scelsi was executive director of the New York State Republican Committee, 1959-1965. Then after serving as Appointments Officer for two years, Governor Nelson Rockefeller appointed Scelsi to the New York State Civil Service Commission.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Stone served as Executive Deputy Secretary of State and then Deputy Commissioner of General Services under Governor Nelson Rockefeller. Stone interview ends at 40 minutes, 23 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Abby O'Neill until end. O'Neill was Nelson Rockefeller's niece.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Storrow worked in Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs; spouse of Public Relations Director (Frank Jamieson) for Nelson Rockefeller's first campaign for the U.S. presidency in 1960. After Mr. Jameison died of cancer in 1960, Governor Rockefeller appointed Storrow the state's official greeter of foreign dignitaries to the city of New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Sutton was a Democratic member of the New York State Assembly in 1965 and 1966, and then Manhattan Borough President from 1966 to 1977.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. The former president of Columbia Broadcasting System (CBS), Taylor co-founded the Sarabam Corporation with Nelson Rockefeller in the late 1970s. Taylor interview ends at 32 minutes, 40 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Joseph Crangle until end. Crangle was New York State Democratic chair.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Teller was a member of the Manhattan Project during World War II and a panelist on the International Security Objectives and Strategy subpanel of Nelson Rockefeller's Special Studies project in the late 1950s, funded by the Rockefeller Brother's Fund.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Teller was a member of the Manhattan Project during World War II and a panelist on the International Security Objectives and Strategy subpanel of Nelson Rockefeller's Special Studies project in the late 1950s, funded by the Rockefeller Brother's Fund.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Terry was Assistant Secretary to the Governor for Nelson Rockefeller from 1959 to 1961. He later served as a Republican in the New York State Assembly and then one term in the U.S. House of Representatives.

scopecontent.p: Interview. Thaler was Republican Party chair of Tompkins County (NY).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Thorne was a campaign aide and advance man for Governor Nelson Rockefeller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Tofany was Republican Party chair of Monroe County at the time of the 1966 New York gubernatorial election.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Troy was a Democratic member of the New York City Council from Queens in the 1960s and 1970s, serving as the leader of the Queens Democratic Party from 1971 to 1974.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Trubin was campaign aide for Governor Nelson Rockefeller who was responsible for negotiating the terms for televised debates.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Trubin was a campaign aide for Governor Nelson Rockefeller who was responsible for negotiating the terms for televised debates.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Underhill was a national affairs writer for Newsweek and then an assistant press secretary for Governor Nelson Rockefeller during the 1964 and 1968 presidential campaigns and the 1966 New York gubernatorial campaign.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Tape contains two interviews with unidentified individuals from Batterymarch Financial Management regarding investing and trading. The first interview ends at 40 minutes, 10 seconds.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Tape contains two interivews with unidentified individuals from General Motors. First interivew ends at 11 minutes, 30 seconds.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Urstadt was Deputy Commissioner of the New York Division of Housing and Community Renewal and then Commissioner in the 1960s and 1970s. He also helped found the Urban Development Corporation and was chair of the Battery Park City Authority in the 1970s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Van Dyk was a senior aide to Vice President Hubert Humphrey and an author. Van Dyk interview ends at 27 minutes, 39 seconds. Tape then contains interview with Gwirtzman until end. Gwirtzman was an advisor and speech writer for John, Robert, and Edward Kennedy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Van Lare was a consultant to states on welfare and related human services programs. He served as executive deputy commissioner and then acting commissioner of the New York Sate Department of Social Services.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Van Ness worked on various health and human services issues in the Program Office and the New York State Health Department, including drug addiction, Medicaid, and Governor Nelson Rockefeller's push for universal health insurance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Vanden Heuvel was Special Counsel to Democratic Governor Averell Harriman of New York in 1958. In 1960, he unsuccessfully ran for Congress against Republican incumbent John Lindsay in New York's 17th district. In the 1970s, Vanden Heuvel served as chair of the New York City Board of Corrections and in 1973 lost the race to incumbent Frank Hogan in the Democratic primary for Manhattan District Attorney.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Vandervoort was a campaign aide to Nelson Rockefeller. Vandervoort interview ends at 153 minutes, 50 seconds. Tape then contains phone call with Reich and a woman at the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library until 160 minutes, 3 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Harry Albright until end. Albright was an aide to Nelson Rockefeller, 1967-1975. During Rockefeller's governorship, Albright held various positions, including deputy secretary, executive secretary, and appointments officer. He was also state banking superintendent, 1972-1974. He then served has Rockefeller's special counsel when Rockefeller was Vice President.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Von Hirsch was an aide to Senator Charles Goodell, a Republican from New York who was appointed by Governor Nelson Rockefeller to fill the Senate seat following the assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy. Von Hirsch interview ends at 84 minutes, 30 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Sam Gould until 93 minutes, 21 seconds. Gould was chancellor of the State University of New York. Tape then contains partial interview with von Hirsch until 130 minutes, 25 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Hayward Plumadore until end. Plumadore was Franklin County Republican chairman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Wagner (a Democrat) was mayor of New York from 1954 to 1965. Wagner interview ends at 68 minutes, 16 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with George Dudley until end. Dudley was an architect and gubernatorial aide to Nelson Rockefeller. Dudley worked alongside Wallace Harrison in designing and building the United Nations, Rockefeller Center, Lincoln Center, and the Empire State Plaza in Albany.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Walker was pastor of the Canaan Baptist Church in Harlem from 1967 to 2004. In the early 1970s, he was a Special Assistant to the Governor on Urban Affairs for Nelson Rockefeller. In 1971, he was one of the negotiators who met with leaders of the Attica prison riot. Before coming to New York, Walker was one of the founders of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC). In 1960, he became the executive director of SCLC and chief of staff to Martin Luther King Jr.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Wallis was a nephew of Mary Todhunter Clark Rockefeller, who was married to Nelson Rockefeller from 1930 to 1962. Wallis interview ends at 128 minutes, 42 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Louis Levine until 134 minutes, 34 seconds. Levine was New York State Industrial Commissioner from 1966 to 1976. Tape then contains partial interview with Ogden Reid until 143 minutes, 43 seconds. Reid was appointed to the New York State Commission on Discrimination in 1961 by Governor Nelson Rockefeller. Reid also served six terms in the U.S. House of Representatives in the 1960s and 1970s. He switched from Republican to Democrat in 1972. Tape then contains partial interview with George Dudely until end. Dudley was an architect who worked with Wallace Harrison to design and build the United Nations, Rockefeller Center, Lincoln Center, and the Empire State Plaza in Albany.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Wallison was Special Assistant to Governor Nelson Rockefeller in the early 1970s. Counsel to the Vice President from 1975 to 1977.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Walsh worked as an assistant attorney general prior to Nelson Rockefeller's tenure and then served in Governor Rockefeller's administrations in as an assistant appointments officer and advance man.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Warburg was a philanthropist and friend of Nelson Rockefeller. He served on the board of trustees at the Museum of Modern Art, 1932-1958, and was a trustee and organizer of MoMA's film library. He was also vice director for public affairs of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1971-1974. In addition, Warburg was a co-founder of the American Ballet and the School of American Ballet.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Watts was director of the Office for Urban Innovationunder for Governor Nelson Rockefeller in the late 1960s. Watts then was staff secretary of Presdient Richard Nixon's National Security Council for 18 months before resigning to protest planned military operations in Cambodia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Weaver was a Dartmouth classmate of and later a campaign advisor to Nelson Rockefeller. He was a pioneer in U.S. television broadcasting, serving as the president of the National Broadcasting Company (NBC) in the 1950s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Weaver was a reporter in the Washington Bureau of the New York Times who covered Nelson Rockefeller for many years as Governor of New York and presidential candidate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Webb was counsel to New York State Assemblyman Perry Duryea and worked on the reapportionment of legislature districts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Weinstein was a Democratic member of the New York State Assembly in the 1960s and majority leader and from 1965 to 1968. In 1969, he was elected to the New York State Supreme Court.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Dr. Wharton's long association with Nelson Rockefeller began with the American International Association for Economic and Social Development (AIA) in 1948. He served as associate and then as director of operations for the American Development Council from 1958 to 1964. He was a member of Nelson Rockefeller's presidential mission to Latin America in 1969 on behalf of Richard Nixon. In October 1969, Wharton was elected president of Michigan State University, becoming the first African-American president of a major U.S. university. In 1978, he became chancellor of the State University of New York (SUNY) system. In 1982, Wharton was named chair of the Rockefeller Foundation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. White was a political consultant and campaign manager for Republican Party and New York Conservative Party candidates. He was also a leader of the Draft Goldwater Committee, 1961-1964.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. White was a political consultant and campaign manager for Republican Party and New York Conservative Party candidates. He was also a leader of the Draft Goldwater Committee, 1961-1964.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Whiteman worked on Governor Nelson Rockfeller's staff in various capacities from 1963 to 1973, including as confidential law assistant and his fourth Counsel to the Governor. He was then Counsel to Governor Malcolm Wilson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Whitney was a Saratoga, NY, socialite known for her excellent race horses.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Widmayer was a Dartmouth classmate of Nelson Rockefeller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Wiebe served under Nelson Rockefeller in the New York State Program Office on the program that led to the Pure Waters Act; also on the Adirondacks Park Commission. Wiebe interview ends at 155 minutes, 15 seconds. Tape then contains partial interivew with Joan Braden until end. Braden was a friend of Nelson Rockefeller and a Rockefeller family aide.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Wiggin was a Dartmouth classmate of Nelson Rockefeller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Williams was on Nelson Rockefeller's staff at the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs (CIAA) and the U.S. Department of Health, Education, and Welfare (HEW).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Wilson was a deputy secretary to Governor Nelson Rockefeller and then special assistant for education to Governor Rockefeller and Governor Hugh Carey. Wilson interview ends at 45 minutes, 16 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with Roswell Perkins until end. Perkins was assistant secretary during Nelson Rockefeller's tenure at the U.S. Department of Health, Education, and Welfare in the mid-1950s and then Counsel to the Governor at the beginning of Rockefeller's first term.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Wilson was Lieutenant Governor of New York during all four of Nelson Rockefeller's terms as Governor, 1959 to 1973. When Rockefeller resigned in 1973, Wilson succeeded him into office. He lost election to the office in 1974. He had started in public service in the New York State Assembly from 1939 to 1958.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Wilson was Lieutenant Governor of New York during all four of Nelson Rockefeller's terms as Governor, 1959 to 1973. When Rockefeller resigned in 1973, Wilson succeeded him into office. He lost election to the office in 1974. He had started in public service in the New York State Assembly from 1939 to 1958.

Wilson interiview ends at 67 minutes. Tape then contains partial interview with John Lockwood until 93 minutes, 33 seconds. Lockwood was chief legal adviser to the Rockefeller family and chair of the New York Public Library. Tape then continues with Wilson interview until end.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Wodell was a friend of Nelson Rockefeller's family in Seal Harbor, Maine. Wodell interview ends at 23 minutes, 25 seconds. Tape then contains partial interview with William Sharkey. Sharkey was chief of revenue estimating for the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance prior to Nelson Rockefeller's administration. He then served in Governor Rockefeller's office starting in 1959, where he focused on tax and budgeting projects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Wolfgang was an advance man for Nelson Rockefeller's gubernatorial campaigns as well as for Governor Rockefeller's 1969 fact-finding mission to Argentina that looked into the embattled military government of Juan Carlos Ongania.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview. Zimmmerman was a lawyer in the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court, eventually rising to chief law assistant. He was then a New York State Supreme Court Justice in the Bronx and counsel to the New York State Republican Senate majority leadership. Zimmerman also served as counsel to the Joint Legislative Committee on Reapportionment and worked on the Waterfront Commmission.
